description:
I am a long-time Henry's Hunan fan. I started going to this North Beach location after the Sansome St. restaurant closed down. I was very pleased to find out that the food here is just as good if not better than the old Sansome St. location! 

My most recommended dishes:

-Ma Po tofu: Spicy tofu with Henry's special meat sauce
-Dianna's Special Meat Pie: Henry's special meat sauce and shredded lettuce between two fried pancake "buns." I would suggest sharing this dish among 3+ people, as it is not as good leftover. 
-Smoked Ham and Green Beans
-Hot and Sour soup: Excellent and spicy.

My only gripe with this place is that the parking is terrible. It's very hard to find an available street parking spot. While this location is temporarily closed, I would recommend trying the Noe Valley restaurant!
author: Haixing K.

description:
I was really, really disappointed this afternoon. I've been eating at Henry's for literally ages. I first ate at the original location since 1974. I **love** their Diana's Meatpie. Sadly, today the meat was dry and crumbly, not savory and moist with drippings. The onion pancakes were soggy and not crunchy. It was so disheartening. This is one of their signature dishes. Something special that no one else offers and it was repugnant to me today. (It pains me to give them only a "mercy rating" of 2 stars when I think they should probably get only a single star.)

The dry, braised green beans were covered in a brown, gooey, tasteless mess. They weren't evenly cooked an not at all slightly crunchy. It was like eating something from a can. I can't understand what is going on here. The Sacramento Street location is still good. Alright, not as stupendous as they were in the past. But they at least make a bit of the wonderful food this restaurant chain was revered for in the past.

No crispy pieces of rice in the chicken fried rice. No texture, just gummy rice. I could go on, but it's almost too depressing.

Even their own web page doesn't mention that the Sansome location is no longer in operation. They could try to keep things up to date. It is just another detail that seems to have gone by the wayside.

Overall it was a very disappointing luncheon. Made even worse by all the hype I gave my friend over what a great dining experience I'd enjoyed there decade after decade after decade. I'm sooooo sad . . . 

Did they not train the cooks at this location to prepare things the way they do elsewhere? I have a copy of their cookbook and will gladly send them a photocopied one for their reference.
author: Bruce S.

description:
So I was really excited that Henry finally reopened considering it's the closes to my house and convenient. I ordered take out and had the most weirdest experience while waiting...
1. The lady that took my order was all over the place, she didn't know much English or was just very scatter brain. Took my order and forgot what I'd ordered. Ask for a number once food came out? I didn't realize I had a order number...
2. My order had one of the dish with chicken, I did not get chicken in it but she charged me for it.
3. My total cost came to 29.00 she ask me to just sign the paper I paid with a card...
4. My charge on my bank statement said 34? So they decided to give themselves a tip for takeout? 
I am very disappointed at the poor staffs taking order and over charging me for takeout? She didn't give me a receipt but when I signed the receipt the total was 29, but now it's 34? I rather walk two more blocks to My Canh off Broadway. Sorry Henry, total disappointment for your reopening. My food was way tooo much msg, I don't care if they claim they don't use it. Trust me they do. And they also charge you tips without you knowing. Please check your receipt and ask for one! Or just be aware. I'm no loner ever going there again.
author: Lily Ann L.

description: My Broccoli beef came with no beef, at all. The chicken was dry. The egg rolls were actually spring rolls. The lady came out of the kitchen wearing sandals.
author: Anna R.

description:
First off, I am huge fan of Henry's Hunan. Love their food and have been to all their locations.

Took some out of towners after talking it up to moon and left pissed off with the service. The waiter had major attitude and was mad at us since they could not understand us. Would have been totally fine if he had asked us to slow down  I know it was not an issue on our end...let me just leave it at that. 

I was embarrassed to bring my guests here.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Loved the food here! 
Went for dinner over the weekend; it was pretty busy. Got a table in minutes. 
We got a bowl of vegetarian hot and sour soup, egg rolls, vegetable chow-mien, vegetable fried rice, king pao tofu and hot and sour vegetables. EVERYTHING was delicious and perfectly portioned. The stars of the dinner were definitely the soup and Kung Pao Tofu. 
Friendly servers, clean restaurant and quick service. Definitely going back to try the other vegetarian dishes. Great pick for vegetarian as they have plenty of options and can customize the ones they do not.
author: HCfoodler C.

description: Everything was undersauced or oversauced, too mild. Order was missing an item and even the white rice was terrible. I didn't know it was possible to mess that up! I've had better experiences with in-restaurant dining, just stay away from take out.
author: Lauren R.

description:
I wasn't too much a fan of the storied Henry's Hunan on Sansome but this North Beach outpost has won me over.

I found the food at the Sansome location to be overly salty but this location gets it right. Great balance of savory with heat and spice. Really enjoyed the combination of ingridients in Henry's Special. The shrimp, scallop, chicken, and crisp veggies come together really well and the hot and spicy bean sauce brings the dish together. Love the richness that the fermented beans bring. The Mongolian beef is really tender and flavorful too. Perhaps a tad oily but nothing unbearable. Grab some white rice to soak in all the sauce. 

Henry Hunan has become a nice neighborhood spot for Chinese. Yes Chinatown's round the corner but it's a comfortable space here and folks are really friendly and attentive. They have lunch specials too.
author: Jon L.

description:
Fantastic unique Chinese food, great flavors and fresh. Also reasonably priced. When they say spicy, they mean it! But I love it.

We ordered the pork noodles to give my son some (but of course he didn't eat them), the meat pie (kind of like a tostada in a way), the string beans (delish) and Marty's special - spicy (the winner of the day). Will definitely be back!
author: Ian W.

description: Really great basic Chinese. Not fancy but great value and flavor! I would go back for sure
author: Costanza Z.

description:
I had not been to Hunan since the days when they were only located on Sansome. I was happily surprised to see them right in North Beach and we stopped in for a late lunch and to introduce my daughter to Diane's pie

There were only two other people inside and no music on so it was quiet. Our server brought the menus quickly and we ordered. After asking she brought a pot of hot tea. The teapot was dirty. I stuck with my water.

The Diana's special meat pie was as good as I remembered it! It's fried, flakey and filled with meat sauce, Parmesan cheese, vegetables and onions. You can request as much hot sauce in it as you like.

We also had Henry's special which is chicken, shrimp, scallops and vegetables in a hot bean sauce. That was also very good but they forgot our white rice and we had to ask for it again.

We finished and waited a long time, I finally headed up to the front to try and get our bill. I would give the food a 4 but the service only a 2.5.
author: Mary B.

description: This is by far some of the most abysmally bad authentic Chinese I have ever had the pleasure of dining on anywhere in this country including the greater Bay Area. The meat is greasy and fatty and sinewy, they overseason everything, they basically throw stuff on the plate. Utterly horrible. Pick another Chinese place.
author: Jason P.

description: The food tasted very fresh and flavorful.  We ordered egg rolls, dumplings, beef with broccoli, and curry chicken.  The egg rolls may have been some of the best I've ever had.  They taste like they were rolled to order and not overly fried.  The Curry Chicken had a lot of spice and not overly saturated with yogurt.  The beef was fresh and not overly sauced.  I look forward to going back.
author: Shaun W.

description: I found this restaurant by accident :) - we were actually headed to Chubby Noodle but was told their wait time was 40 minutes. So we walked around and found this cute Chinese restaurant around the corner. I ordered dishes all from the Chinese menu (with English translation), we had the Hunan beef stir-fry, shredded potato, and cabbage. Everything tasted pretty good and the portion was BIG. The only thing that needed a bit more improvement was probably their service: our tea pot was empty and I signaled to get it refilled, but it never did. But other than that I am quite happy with the food!
author: Yuan Z.

description:
I love Italian food, but was so relieved to see an Asian restaurant in North Beach (basically Little Italy). Sometimes you're just craving Asian food ya know? After bar hopping on a Saturday night, I stopped by around 8pm and was seated right away. Service was efficient and friendly, and our food arrived pretty quickly. Plus, I like that it's not expensive for such a pricey neighborhood! 

We got the hot and sour chicken and one of their rice dishes and both were absolutely delicious. I'm used to sweet and sour chicken, but not hot and sour chicken so this was a new dish for me. It tastes just like the soup, but is a thicker sauce. The chicken was cooked really well. The rice had the most fantastic flavor. I can't really explain it, but let's just say I wish that plate would keep refilling itself. 

I would definitely recommend!
author: Emma W.

description: Great Hunan food and excellent service. Reasonable price too given the location. I highly recommend for anyone in the area.
author: Maria R.

description: We have finally given up trying to find good Chinese anywhere else than our place at home in Irvine. We ordered everything mild and it was so spicy, even for my husband that loves spice. I ended up whipping all the sauce from the chicken just so I could at least eat something. I would not recommend this place, just go eat something that San Francisco is known for like great seafood. We ordered the special with scallops, shrimp and chicken - there were 2 shrimps and maybe 1 whole scallop and a ton of vegetables. Not good.
author: Jennifer G.

description: Umm..what am I supposed to say about Henry's Hunan? You wanna know why I dragged my date here? I read a Yelp review where the Yelper reported that they had a Mark Zuckerberg sighting at the Henry's Hunan in Noe Valley. That was a long time ago, and I had wanted to try Henry's because of that....but my report is that this is not a very good restaurant. 4 stars on Yelp? Palease. Well, the interior is nice and the menu is presentable. It all looks good on paper, but it looks and tastes like stir-fried cabbage and meat bits. Is every single dish stir-fried with greasy oil? I think so. The dishes have large servings, but it is quality not quantity after all. I know that this is not where Hong Kong people go out to eat Chinese. I must have suckered myself into thinking I'd like mushu pork pancakes. HAHA. Henry's Hunan in San Francisco. I do not feel the need to try it ever again. I can stir-fry cabbage and salty meat at home. I cannot believe Henry's has 6 locations.
author: Denise C.

description: An old favorite, dating back many years to when we first lived in the Bay Area and visited the original hole-in-the-wall Hunan.  Still the best onion cakes, and we loved the Diana's special version.  Meaty and satisfying, balancing the spicy minced pork with the crispy, cooling lettuce.  Wonderful eggplant, which basks in a richly flavorful garlic sauce.  As always, well done.
author: Bill M.

description:
My first visit to San Francisco with Mari we found the most delicious fried rice ever at Chef Jia's.  The flavors from the wok, the seasonings, and the meats were divine.  After they closed we have tried the fried rice at many places but none have been as good.  Seeing as Chef Jia's was a Hunan restaurant I had high hopes for Henry's Hunan.

Combo fried rice with smoked ham, chicken, beef, and shrimp.  While the chicken & beef didn't have too much flavor the smoked ham had a complex smoky and savory flavor.  Shrimp was good but there were not very many of them and they were tiny.  The rice and egg didn't have too much flavor either.  Next time I'm getting the smoked ham fried rice.

While the ham was excellent here I am going to keep searching for the one perfect fried rice dish like I had at Chef Jia's.
author: Soo H.

description:
Henry's Hunan is a great spot to grab Chinese food in North Beach and relatively inexpensive (came to $15 pp). We came when it was pretty much empty so service was speedy and attentive. 

We started with the dumplings and they were excellent! Perfectly cooked and juicy pork filling. And the best part is they make their own chili oil which is phenomenal with the dumplings. (I tend to rate Chinese restaurants based on their homemade chili oil haha). Highly recommend this dish!

For entrees we shared Henry's Special and the Chicken Fried Rice and they were solid! Henry's Special comes with hunan chicken, shrimp, scallops, carrots, and oyster mushrooms in a flavorful and mildly spicy sauce. I was pleased that the scallops were cooked well and not overdone which is an easy thing to get wrong. The fried rice was excellent! Subtle flavors and nicely grilled chicken pieces - well done.

All in all I'd come again and likely stick to these same orders :)
author: Sabina S.

description:
Ate here last weekend because my boyfriend loves the Henry's Hunan chain and wanted to bring me for my first time. Our visit left a lot to be desired for me. 

Ambiance - Walked in at 7:30pm on a Saturday night...the restaurant was empty minus one couple. Pretty surprising given its prime location in North Beach. The restaurant has relatively chic furniture/decor for a no-frills Chinese restaurant. Clean. Casual. Had the Warriors game on a large LCD. Seems to cater to mainly non-Asian clientele.

Service - Typical Chinese restaurant service. They take your order quickly after sitting down and are prompt bringing food out, but good luck trying to get their attention other than to take your order and bring your bill. 

Food - We ordered the onion pancake, dumplings, sweet and sour soup, kung pao chicken, spicy & hot rock cod fillets, and spicy eggplant with meat sauce. Mostly, everything was just OK. The onion pancake was very different from the scallion pancakes I'm familiar with - it was crispy and flaky. The eggplant was visually unappetizing and lacked unique favoring. Everything else was unmemorable.

Pricing is decent given its location and ambiance. Food is barely a step up from Panda Express, but in a sit-down restaurant. All-in-all, it was alright, but I don't plan on returning given the other Chinese food options in SF.
author: Vivian N.

description: Closed for renovation. Did n't say that on yelp. Either yelp or Henry should have posted that. Annoying after finding a parking spot and time wasted.
author: Stanley S.

description: I'm a little confused, is this place under new ownership? Ordered take out here tonight and not only did the food take a half hour longer than they said it would but it was all horrrrrrrrrrible. The fried rice was badly burnt the hot and sour soup was water with vinegar and a pound of peppers and the chicken was sinewy. We are so sad we used to love this place. Would give it one star but we gave two I'm hopes that is was just an off night.
author: mackenzie e.

description: The business is OPEN!! They updated their in dining experience.  Amazing food.  Recommend dumplings, dianna meaty pie.  Marty's special and kung pao chicken yummy!   YELP needs to change the status to OPEN!!!
author: T M.

description: H-e-n-r-e-e-e!!!  Even though this Henry Hunan has a different atmosphere to it, but the food orders are not greased up like many places in Chinatown eateries, so I feel very full with their take-out meals and I feel healthy afterwards.
author: BanBan T.

description: I really like Lo Mein, but unfortunately did not find it on their menu, so I ordered the Chow Mein instead, which was okay. The flavor was a little bit odd. Portion was generous, pricing was OK. Restaurant looks clean.
author: Marie D.

description:
This quickly became one of my go-to Chinese food spots anytime I visit SF. The food is easily 5 stars, as everything I've tried has been fresh, authentic, and delicious. It's a somewhat small place with about 12 tables, but it's extremely clean and has a simple, modern atmosphere. 

They start you off with tea, which is a rarity these days unless you're getting dim sum. We always order the hot & sour soup, which is hands down the best I've ever had. We've tried the Kung Pao chicken, Mongolian beef, stir fry string beans (really good), and the garlic chicken. I try to get something different every time I go, since I have yet to be disappointed by anything. 

The only reason I didn't bump to 5 stars is because the service is hit or miss. The first time we came, it was just OK, but it was pretty busy. The second time, it was excellent and super quick and this last time was pretty slow, and there was no crowd. Their prices are definitely inexpensive for the area, and again, it's cleaner than most of the places we've tried in Chinatown so we'll continue to come whenever we're in town.
author: Kate K.

description: Definitely choose the Chinese menu if you can. They will be completely diff than the ones you taste from English menu.
author: Chun J.

description:
We noticed the teacups were dirty. 
No big deal, asked for new ones.

Looked down at my "clean" plate, there's a piece of rice on it. 
Ok, maybe they had a really busy lunch, had to move fast to reset.

Got a glass of wine, came with lipstick on the rim.

Completely turned off now. But we already ordered food and didn't want to just walk out the door. They gave us chicken even though we ordered pork. Didn't apologize for the dirty plates or glassware. Food was mediocre, so pretty much a disaster. 

Not sure how they got such high ratings.
author: Ana P.

description: Very good and fresh food. I had the kung pao chicken,my wife had the orange chicken and Henry's special  for my daughter. Everything came out promptly and fresh. Extremely good flavor and would definitely come back here again. Awesome place!!
author: Jonathan C.

description: The food here is great! It reminds me of my mom's home cooked food. But they are closed for earthquake remodeling temporarily.
author: Cece M.

description:
If you are a big fan of spicy food and want to try out some authentic Hunan food, you should definitely come to Henry's and ask for the special menu (normally only served for Chinese people).

Hunan food, also known as Xiang cuisine, is very well known for its hot spicy flavor, fresh aroma and deep color (wiki). Although the secret menu at Henry's only contains ~20 dishes, I have the confidence that all of them are super tasty based on my experience on 8 of them.

We had Hunan lamb, braised pork, port with pepper, ribs with pepper, chicken with acid beans, etc.. Although I admitted that they look very plain nothing fancy, the taste is 100% Hunan food and good examples of them: spiciness from different kinds of peppers, chewy meat, strongly flavored lamb and perfect with rice. Each of them had reminded me the flavor of real China and Chinese food. I had not had such authentic Chinese food for so long that Henry's really impressed me and my friends. I will definitely come here more often!
author: Xian S.

description: Take out food was not good .The SOMA location is way better .
author: Vish E.

description:
We came on a Sunday evening, no wait and we sat near a window. Parking was difficult but the area was walkable. We had egg rolls, hot and sour vegetables, dumplings and chicken lo mein along with moo shi. 

Will come back. It's a few blocks from Chinatown. Restaurant was clean and staff friendly and efficient.
author: Patrick P.

description:
We've been coming here as "locals" for over two years. Food is consistently very, very good -probably one of the best "basic" Chinese restaurants in the area. It's an attractive space. (No fluorescent lights!)

One issue we have is that in the past year or so, the service seems to have declined significantly. The wait staff now are young women who stick by the cash register (out of sight lines to many tables) and always seem to be talking very loudly to other employees (in kitchen?).

Less loud yakking by staff and more anticipating needs (water refills, additional drinks, etc) would make this place a delight. Could be a real gem.
author: Letty B.

description:
When I lived in the neighborhood, this place was a weekly treat. Having tasted many of the Chinese restaurants in the North Beach / Chinatown area this was consistently my favorite. 

Louis, the owner, is sweet and charismatic and scrambles around to make sure everybody's happy. You can tell right away he's the glue that holds this place together. When I came in with the sniffles, he sent me on my way with magical Won Ton soup to cure my cold. 

Henry's always tastes fresh to me - with deliciously spicy, clean flavors. And Diana's meat pie is a MUST. Start with that. End with that. Just make sure you try it. Slather it with the homemade chili sauce for a truly spiritual experience. 

I always order the Kung Pao chicken with a side of broccoli - a meal that perfectly satiates without feeling too heavy. But for kids or picky eaters, I would recommend the Orange Chicken - it's sweet and tangy. I've ordered the Garlic Chicken plate as well and enjoyed it. One thing - the plates do not come with rice so it is an extra charge (I believe). 

With hearty and fresh tasting food, sweet and caring staff, and a modern but cozy atmosphere, I would recommend filling your belly with Henry's before hitting the bars on Grant or with a friend on a cold, rainy evening.
author: Ainslee S.

description: What Outstanding Food!  We've been there 4 times now (and used "take out" once). The room is airy and clean, the staff gracious, and the meals are the best (we had the BEST Combo Chow Mein I've ever had the other day). Oh, and the prices are truly reasonable. The R and G Lounge used to be our favorite. Henry's chef beats them hands down!
author: Dick L.

description:
Best Chinese food you'll find in the city. 
The service is not always great but food arrives fast and it's worth sitting through. 
Get the meat pie as an appetizer, it'll be the best appetizer you've ever had.
author: Matt C.

description:
Service was fast and food was tasteful. Would come back if was in town. 
Items ordered:
Mongolian Chicken
Chicken chow mein 
Chicken fried rice (a little salty, but it was ok for my preference) 
Hunan Spareribs
Garlic chicken
Combination fried rice and chow mein

There was a lot of us
author: Rochelle E.

description:
Every once in a while I feel adventurous & decide to order from a different Chinese restaurant.  

And every time after I've done this, I always go back to Henry's.

Here are all the reasons why...

Their spicy curry chow mein.  I do it w pork.  No joke about the spicy.  It's fantastic.

Their fried rice is the most un-fried rice I've ever had.  Light & fluffy.  Zero grease.  Though, depending on your preference, that could be a good or a bad thing.  I wish they did a barbecue pork fried rice instead of their version, which is w diced thin ham, but it's not a big deal.

Diana's meat pie.  This is a dish that was introduced to me here.  I'd like to personally thank Diana.  I have no idea who she is, but I just love her meat pie.  The beef filling is rich, tender, & uber flavorful.  The crust is tender & flaky; the perfect encasement.  When this puppy is piping hot, it hits the peak levels of deliciousness.  Something to be devoured, not merely eaten.

Honorable mention goes to the sweet & sour chicken, & the chicken salad.

Props for the food always being fresh, & delivery always being on time.

There are 7 Henry's in the city.  Each one is run by a family member.  Nice.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Good food and service. A bit pricey for certain items but it is SF, so what can ya do?
author: Thoughtful D.

description: This is the 4th time I visited and the quality is going down hill. The food is really salty and pricy. Not gonna come back even though I live in the neighbourhood.
author: Vy T.

description: Tourists from Cleveland. Stopped in for lunch on a Saturday. We were the only customers. The food was fresh made and outstanding. Washed down with Thai iced tea.
author: Richard R.

description: Made reservations  for 730 and we were seated promptly . The service  was a little slow to start. Once we ordered the food came quickly.  Tried their meat pie . This tasted like Indian fry bread . Moo shu pork was tasty but also very salty. The tofu was horrible . Garlic chicken  came highly recommended  but it was overcooked and bland. We did like the Mongolian beef but it was mostly onions. I would try it again but definitely  ask them to lower the salt
author: Anthony K.

description: The food is made with burnt oil and totally overwhelmed the flavors. Couldn't finish my dish... too bad had good expectations of the place
author: Arturo I.

description:
Dirty smudgey plates, gross salty food, cup had lip stick on it and the replacement had breadcrumbs, and the food came one by one for our group of six. I had finished by the time the last plate came, and that plate was the rice...
This place is empty for a reason, four stars and right by chinatown? Come on...
author: BayArea C.

description:
Let me preface to say that the food was just okay, nothing special, and like most other reviewers have said, quite salty. Unfortunately, that is not where the main problem lies. The service was abysmal; the male server was short and barely let us finish our order before walking away. After roughly 7 minutes, our food came out at staggered times. In addition, the brown rice we ordered also never came to our table. 

After we ate the food, which contained an abnormally large amount of onions, we waited for quite some time for the check before my sister decided to walk up to the front to pay. About a minute later I hear my sister arguing with the staff. When she comes back to the table she informs our group that they charged the tax twice, as well as charge an additional $10 for a dishwasher tax (wtf). Basically a bill that should have been around 50, turned into 70 for no reason. Oh also that brown rice we never received? It was kept on the bill and we were told that it was just added to the white rice we had ordered. By this point we were just done and decided to leave after practically forcing the bill down. 

I guess the thing to take from this review is that if you decide to go here, expect to be swindled on the bill. Make sure you get what you order and check the bill before paying.
author: Alex M.

description:
The food here is actually really delicious. The service is quick and the place is super duper kept. 

I had the vegetable chow mein and some spring rolls. No complaints. Its in such a Good area too. 

Id for sure be back next time i visit the bay.
author: Ella A.

description:
It's almost like I did my Yelp research, decided on a spot to grab good Chinese food, then walked into the entirely wrong place or an alternate universe. 

The girl serving me spoke literally almost no English (no problem, I'm Asian), and got my main order completely wrong (noodles instead of rice). That's fine - I was hungry so I ate it when it came. 

Their food is complete and utter oily disgusting pig slop. I ate less than a third of my food despite being ravenous and just had to bail out. 

You would find better Chinese food at a shittily run Panda Express than this place. 

My God - what did you just do to me, Yelp? Four star average? GTFO.
author: Jon Z.

description:
We didn't realize this was a chain until we went to the wrong one before we went to this location, but it was delicious.

Since we had not really eaten all day, we were starving and ordered a bottle of wine, egg rolls, dumplings, chow mien, orange chicken,many Kung po chicken for three people!

The bill came at about $70 which wasn't terrible because the bottle of wine was $30. 

The only weird thing is each dish came out one by one. First egg rolls, the dumplings, then orange chicken,mother chow mien, then finally the Kung po.

Either way the food was delicious!
author: Mallory E.

description:
Hunan food that warms and comforts the palate with its tasty, stir-fried entrees!

As starters, do get their signature Meat Pie, Dumplings and Hot and Sour Soup!  You can't go wrong with that opening combo! 

For entrees, I do recommend their Mushu Pork, Beef and String Beans and Hot and Sour Chicken.  All three of these dishes are unique and tingles the palate in its own delightful way!

The service was attentive and accommodating. 

It's a cozy, tight-knit spot in North Beach!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Spicy yet delicious! The Henry special was packed with flavor and the mango loan beef was so tender. The portions were too big, so an order is enough for 2 or 3 people. The vegetable egg fried rice was so yum and so were the noodles.
author: Hanan A.

description:
Food was decent and place was clean.  A step up from a Panda Express type of place.  A bit sterile compared to the authentic Chinese restaurants I go with my Asian friends.  Mainly caters to non Asians as the menu was completely in English.  

Service to non Asian clientelle was better than for us even though we were there before the other parties.   For example, the other parties had their waters regularly refilled without request, but we had to hail the servers to get similar service.  The numbers between the other parties and us were similar.  The only difference was that we were Asian while the other parties were non Asian.

If you want authentic Hunan chinese food and decent service, best to avoid.  Don't take Asian friends or family unless you want to be ridiculed as being non Asian.
author: Charles L.

description:
The ambiance looked nice. Clean and modern. However, there was a lack of music which I find makes part of the dining experience. 

The tea pot came and it was dirty. It looked like they just picked it up from another table who finished eating and  brought it over. I ordered the spicy eggplant and the fiancé ordered the fish dish. We also ordered a fried tofu dish to share as stated on the menu 

The food was ok...nothing special but super duper greasy. The tofu definitely was not fried which was a little disappointing given the description. We asked the server and she said it was fried but not deep fried so we just left it at that.

Mediocre food. Dirty teapot = huge turn off. Not coming back.
author: Nancy T.

description:
Saturday afternoon. Two other tables inside. Ridiculously slow service and because of what looked like a dinner between all the staff at one table. Reason for 3 stars instead of 4.

The dumplings were amazing. My friend doesn't eat pork, I don't think he noticed. Lol. We scarfed them down. They were delish.

Beef and string beans is good but very MSG tasting. The beef is so tenderized it falls apart on the dish. Slightly off putting but has nice flavor.

Kung pao chicken was great. Chicken seemed to be of great quality. Overall  I think the place was great. It got a lot of good reviews considering the real Chinatown is up the block.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Great ambiance.  Food is slightly above average for the area.  However the chef needs to hold on the salt.   Fried rice doesn't need salt.   I had the Mongolian beef and it was relatively well seasoned.   Again salt was the main issue though. 

Outside of this, the service was excellent and I really appreciate the decor.   The chicken chow mein did not get the salt treatment so I can recommend this.  

Yes I would eat here again.   

PS.   Not certain which  restaurant  the 1 star fellow was commenting on but this place is incredibly clean.
author: C A.

description:
This is my brother's favorite Chinese restaurant.   He highly recommends the Hunan Smoked Ham which is stir fried wuthering bell pepper, onion and carrots.   I tried it but it was very salty and spicy, IMO.  
I had the dumplings, which were just okay.  I also had onion rolls or fritters.   It was an appetizer.  It left me wondering what it was and why I ordered it.   Four stars because my brother LOVED his dish and the place was clean.
author: Sharon F.

description:
The food was good, but definitely Americanized. For appetizer, the meat pie was very nice. Asked for extra spicy and was a little disappointed there as it was fairly mild. 

Main courses of harvest pork (twice cooked pork by another name) and Rock Cod fillets. Pork was Average and fish tasted as if they had been frozen. Also had curry vegetables, which were standard American veggies, broccoli, carrots, peppers, etc. 

Given the proximity to Chinatown the food was a little disappointing. 

Only other issue was the overall salt level was a little too high. 

The place was very clean and inviting, the staff was very courteous and the service was very good.
author: David O.

description: I was the only diner last night until a couple wandered in just before my departure - although, to be fair, there were several take-away pickups. That really says it all. The brown rice was good and the waitress was attentive. Don't think it's worth a trip to try another dish.
author: Bruce B.

description:
The ambiance of this place is definitely not hole in the wall, but the prices seemed like they were! I felt like eating something warm and comforting so I go the Wonton Soup, which I never do because my mom can easily make it at home, but it definitely hit the spot after a long day of being out. There wasn't a ton of wontons, but it was enough to keep me satisfied. They were pretty good but not anything special. The broth was night and light and really good. I tried some of my friend's food and it was pretty good as well, and the portions are pretty generous. When we saw the check, we were surprised at how low the total was considering it was a nice Chinese restaurant in the middle of SF, but we were happy with it.

Overall, it's a nice and clean restaurant with good food and decent prices.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Very clean and cute place in a tourist-y area.  The decor is modern and spacious -- it might be small but doesn't give you like this ghetto hole-in-the-wall vibe.  It's near a whole bunch of hotels -- I met with a friend here for a work trip who was staying in the nearby Holiday Inn.  

Service is fairly fast but they don't rush you to be done like a lot of Asian places.  A few things to recommend: 

1) the meat pie -- interesting dish lol.  2 fried pies (like Taiwanese scallion pie but without the scallion) with zesty ground beef and lettuce in between.  4 big pieces.

2) chicken chow mein -- not too salty or greasy.  Very good.  Go ahead and get it spicy -- it's not overwhelming.

3) kung pao chicken -- authentic, not Panda Express style.  Very good -- not too saucy and the serving size was pretty decent.  With rice, fed two people.  We got it medium spicy and it wasn't too hot (and I can't handle spice much).  

4) curry chicken -- yum!  I wasn't expecting too much out of this but it was delicious.  

Rice serving size is also decent.  All the prices were cheap for this area -- I was expecting to be robbed b/c of its proximity to Fisherman's Wharf.  Fair warning - parking is not easy in this area so expect to possibly walk a bit but the neighborhood is safe and tourist-friendly.  Overall, yum!
author: Anita T.

description:
My family went to Henry's Hunan for dinner last night and had a great time. The food is super authentic and delicious, and the prices are totally reasonable! We went specifically for the meat pie because we heard it was one of a kind. It's worth making a trip over there JUST for the meat pie. The only way to explain is it like a Chinese tostada. We also ordered the Mo Si soup (perfect portion for three people), the pork fried rice with an egg (my favorite dish of the night), the Kung Pao shredded pork, and the dry-sauteed string beans. The only mediocre item was the string beans and only because they weren't cooked long enough. The beers are only 3.50 and you get hot tie right when you sit down. 

The only reason this place gets four stars instead of five is because of the service. It was some of the slowest service I've experienced in a very long time, and the place was not that crowded. Not only did the food come out item by item (with 5-10 minutes in between), but when we would ask for something (like a glass of water or soy sauce) our server would forget and we'd have to remind him once or twice more. Getting the bill also took quite some time. Regardless, we will definitely be coming back, and ordering our Chinese takeout from there.
author: Regina L.

description:
Bad bad customer service!! 
Food was good but our table was overcharged. We asked for an itemized bill, in english, and he started yelling our order at us. Then a woman came out and told us "pay the bill, just split it" Then we pulled out the menu and started writing everything out and the price, that's when they really got mad and started saying that we needed to wash dishes. We added up our order, included tax and tip and came up $30 less than what our bill came out to. The waiter then tells us that we forgot to add $1.25 per person for the side of rice that we thought was included because no one ordered a side of rice. So embarrassing!
author: Erica G.

description:
Well, I really wanted to rate this place higher after my first experience, but based on my last two, I really can't.  My main beef is that the customer service is TERRIBLE.  Like, really bad. Today, I was seated for over 15 minutes before anyone even came over to see what I wanted - or gave me a place setting - or water - or anything.
  
I ordered the Henry's Shredded Pork, "a local favorite" - and the first time I was there, it was delicious, which is why I came back.   It's noted as  "spicy" and had a great spicy kick to it -
 then.  And then there was today.  What happened?  Did the chef quit?  It had no spice, heat, or any flavoring in it whatsoever!  In fact, it was one of the blandest meals I've ever had.  And it was cold. Oh, and once the food is delivered, forget about EVER seeing your wait person again!  He/She is GONE and will not return to your table until he/she delivers your bill (which seems to happen when they notice you are standing up and putting on your jacket to leave).  So based on  all of this, I will not be coming back.
author: M. S.

description: Below average food (tried three different dishes-chicken, seafood, and rice) and they didn't bring out the dumplings that we had ordered as an appetizer.  We were still charged for the dumplings and had to have the waitress change our bill-no apology or comp provided.  I see why its busy (on Grant = drunk bar food) but I wouldn't return again and would probably satisfy any food craving with the amazing italian in the area, or walk a few blocks to Chinatown.
author: Raina D.

description:
I came here Thursday night with my boyfriend. We wanted some great Chinese food, so we looked on yelp and found this place. 

Parking: On the street where you have to pay meters
Location: In a cute neighborhood where some of the MUNI transit trains run

Once my boyfriend and I walked into the restaurant, we were greeted right away. We got to choose our seating. We sat in a booth where there were pillows. It was a little dimmed in the restaurant, and the booth was extremely comfortable. First thing we noticed about the menu was that the prices weren't bad at all, and the restaurant gave you  good amount off food. 

We ordered dumplings (Filled with pork and vegetables. He preferred them spicy), beef with broccoli, shrimp fried rice, and chicken chow mein. All the food was amazing. The only things I did not like was that they didn't give us too much beef with broccoli, and the chicken chow mein was a bit salty to my boyfriend and I. Besides those two things, all the food came out hot and very quickly. My boyfriend and I were extremely satisfied and full. It had been a while since him and I ate great Chinese food, so we are pleased to put this restaurant down as one of the good places to grab food from. 

The service: There seemed to be one girl mainly serving everyone. She was a bit inattentive. She didn't notice I even needed water until I was fully done with my meal. Also, my boyfriend and I couldn't flag her down for some sweet and sour sauce, so we ended up disturbing another waiter. 

Concluding, the food was pretty good besides the chow mein being a little bit salty. The meal portions were pretty good for the price you pay. It was the right amount of portions for my boyfriend and I that is. Not sure if their portions would be big enough for a group of 4 or so depending on how many orders you get. We got 4 different ones. Also, our waitress was a bit distracted when it wasn't even that busy in the restaurant.
author: Ashley M.

description:
The food is is just a good as all the other locations.

I think the draw here is the service - borderline rude and incompetent. Almost like having to deal with good ol' Edsel Ford Fung at the old Sam Wo, or ordering a hotdog at the Wieners Circle in Chicago - but not nearly as entertaining. Not by a long shot.

Still, I think people come here so that they can say they survived the experience. Maybe.

I completely understand if you have that hankering for Henry's specialties. I get that way, too. The food is that good. 5 Stars. 

But the service at this particular location - ugh. 1 Star.

Which I why I give this particular joint a generous 3 Stars. 

My advice: enjoy the great food at Henry's - just at another location.
author: V. L.

description: I've been coming to Henry's Hunan since the last couple of years. For me, its the best Hunan style food you can get in the city. Its hot, spicy and the quality is the same at each of its locations (Mission, FiDi). Kung pao chicken is the way to go when ordering here.
author: Mahesh L.

description: I have been a regular for both take-out and dine in and have really liked Henry Hunan as a staple in North Beach, as well as the friendly staff. However, they seemed to have changed owners, though denied it when I asked recently. The staff is completely new, though they've kept the menu relatively the same. Unfortunately, this is my last time going to Henry's. Yesterday, I ordered the chicken salad, and within an hour came down with symptoms of food poisoning.
author: Sonya Y.

description:
Very clean restaurant in not so clean area of China Town. 
Food and service was good.
author: Dylan R.

description: It took at least 15-20 minutes sitting at the table before anyone took our order. It wasn't crowded. We started out with the dumplings and they were sooooo good! Seriously, I was sad when we finished them. Delicious! I ordered Henry's special or something like that- chicken, shrimp, scallops and veggies. The meats were good, the shrimp was fresh although not always deveined completely. The sauce wasn't my favorite. I ordered this dish mild and I don't know if that affected the flavor but I'd guess not. I still enjoyed the meat, but I would've liked a tasty sauce- a girl needs more than a plate of meat. The veggies were minimal. The carrots were sliced thin as paper which seemed unnecessary. The rice was good but you need to order it separately. The drinks are cans which I actually like but 1.75 for a can is a lot. My husband got Kung pow chicken and said he would rate his meal a 4/5.
author: Reba B.

description:
Great Food! Good dining experience!

Fast Service and Great Fried Rice,....North Carolina born and bred but want some gud Ol Chinese Food whilst out hur in NorCal.

Thanks Henry!
author: Gembo A.

description:
This place is pretty decent. It has a nice decor, service is fast, most of the food is pretty good. We got the eggplant, kung pao beef, Henry's special, and some cold noodles. Pretty much everything was good except the eggplant, so don't get that I suppose.

In short it was a good place to get a meal and I would come again.
author: Alex Z.

description: We came here every week since they opened but last week there was an entirely new staff. Went to a different henrys hunan and found out that the ownership changed. This is not the same place. The rest of the locations are still part of the same family but this one is no longer.
author: Tom W.

description: Disappointed with the flavor of food and service. Eggplant was bland so sent it back and they added garlic sauce and made it a bit better. Bamboo shoots in the hot and sour soup were chewy. Sweet and sour chicken was neither sweet nor sour. Their restroom was city too. Not going back there again even though the fried rice was good
author: Vin M.

description:
Really good & very accommodating! We had a 4 month old & needed our lunch to be quick & not spicy for nursing Mom. They did both & the food was so delicious, even without the spice. 

Would highly recommend!
author: sue h.

description: Perfect end to an evening in Chinatown. Wonderful food and calming atmosphere. The food was a bit more Chinese-American than other places. There were many authentic Chinese joints in Chinatown but we were not brave enough to try them. We ordered the chicken salad, Hunan beef, and sweet-and-sour chicken. We were very happy with all of them.
author: Ben B.

description: It started off horribly from the moment I asked for a simple coke which he forgot and had to come back two minutes later and ask us what we wanteFood was good but don't look forward to their tax on top of tax on top of tax. They tried charging us for an item we didn't order and then said they were charging us 20 dollars on top of our order for the dishwashers and walking the food over. For that price I could of walked to the back and grabbed my own food. Although the food was I did have an issue with the meat to vegetable ratio as well. I got very little chicken in my Kung Pao Chicken. Overall I did not enjoy this visit and will not be coming back to this restaurant.
author: Drew N.

description:
Yeah! Another stellar Henry's Hunan. The decor is fresh and clean and the hits are the same...we always go back to the Meat Pie and the Cold Chicken Noodles. Delicious. Steamed dumplings and the rock cod fillets are other faves.

A great place to stop for lunch if you're shopping on Upper Grant. Such a fun neighborhood.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I work in the area and eat lunch here a lot. The owner is amazing and will accommodate you any way he can, this is the best Henry's location in the city. Super friendly staff and affordable prices for absolutely delicious food. My favorites are: 

Wonton soup
Meat pie
And the fried rice is the best!

I plan on trying other things but I keep going back to my favorites bc I end up craving them!

Go here you will enjoy :)
author: Ashley L.

description:
Right off the bat, the hot and sour soup starter was great. One of the best hot and sour soups I've had. My whole family anticipated a great meal.

The service was great.

Every dish we ordered was fresh and potentially full of great flavor. However -- and the reason I can't give at least another star -- every dish was extremely salty. So salty that I'd wondered if the person cooking couldn't taste the saltiness for some reason. Maybe it was an off day, but the saltiness was unbearable. We had to eat extra portions of rice to help. This is coming from a person who likes food well-salted. In fact, my whole family loves flavor.

As I mentioned, were it not for the saltiness, the dishes would have actually been some of the better Chinese food I've had in San Francisco.

Ultimately, I think I would return again and let them know beforehand to not make the dishes so salty.
author: Kevin L.

description: Wow. This place never was this bad before. I honestly hate giving bad reviews, but the food was so insulting, that I felt like I had to. What happened? New chef?
author: Marcus S.

description: Having waited tables through college, it takes a lot (or more correctly very little) to get me to leave no tip. It's important to note that I have gone here before had decent food and reasonable service. However, tonight I went in and ordered 2 dishes Henry's special and combination chow mein. There was great confusion over Henry's special, and I felt as if I was the only person to ever order it.  It did come to the table quickly, and was very good.  10 minutes later still no noodles. I asked my waitress and she apologized and said she had not understood. More time passed and still no noodles.  I asked again, and was told that there were no noodles coming and "sorry".  Never did get the noodles.
author: Ron W.

description: Super! Spend a lot  time in Hong Kong and  mainland China. It does not get any better, very authentic. Very good service and attentive owner
author: Mark T.

description: I was sick recently and in need of some hot, spicy soup... I had heard good things about Henry's Hot and Sour Soup so I decided to give it a try. OMG, it was good! It's pretty spicy but the flavors are amazing. The dumplings are also a must! They are so fluffy and delicious. Sometimes, if you go in to the restaurant, you can even see them making the dumplings at one of the tables. YUM!
author: Julia M.

description:
Traditional Hunan style. Chinese recommendation. Not American-like-Hunan style. 
地道湖南菜，值得推荐
author: Lai X.

description: So, we showed up between 5:30pm and 6:00pm.  To or surprise, the place was empty except one other table of two.  And we sat.... And we sat.. did I mention we sat?  No one came to see us, take a drink order, anything.  They made eye contact with us often, but it was a long time before anyone every came over.  Finally a young girl came over and dropped of some water.  I will tell you, drink it slowly... You aren't likely to ever see more. They found out there was a large party coming in, and we were no longer thought about.  We were just furniture at that point. There was an older lady who FINALLY came over to take or order after we worked to get her attention.  She was about as friendly and helpful as one of the tables.  She said little, and smiled less (than the table).  We certainly seemed major bother to her for daring to come to the restaurant.  She did manage to take our order, despite her lack of helpfulness or conversation. The soup and food showed up all at once. So much for pacing.  We asked the young girl for two forks since my wife and son aren't good at chopsticks.  She thought I wanted cokes.  I repeated..no.. forks... f... forks. She nodded and repeated forks.  She showed up several minutes later with forks...and cokes.  We ate the rest of the meal never having anyone come to see us.  Good thing the cokes came out accidently... Or we would have run out of water a long time ago.  There is a drought on in California I guess.  The food was good... Not great, but edible.  It took a long while to get our bill... Long enough we thought it might be free.  Finally we paid and got the heck or of there.  Clearly being a customer here was not something anyone wanted and we didn't want to make them dislike customers any more by staying around.
author: Greg M.

description:
My new lunch time spot working out here in the North Beach area.
I've only had their fried rice and I look forward to eating everything else on the menu.
Fried rice is usually my goto dish for a new place. If you mess up fried rice then your other dishes must be cr@p.
Not here at Henry's though, unlike a place down the street whose fried rice was super oily.

The staff here is pleasant, attentive and accommodating.
The prices are very reasonable given the area.
Looking forward to eating here as long as I'm working in the area.
author: Paul U.

description: STOMACH ACHE ALERT The orange chicken was absolutely terrible.... Sorry and I would say coated with a mushy barely edible breading.... But that would mean there would have to be something under the coating.... It was barely any chicken mostly mushy crap... I was looking forward to a nice Sunday take out meal and this place ruined it for me tonite as I spend the rest of my night in bed with stomach pain.
author: Chris T.

description: Best real Chinese food that I had for a long time! Had hot & sour soup, kongpao chicken and spicy ham, every single one of them spicy and (!) tasty.
author: Christoph S.

description:
Gluten Free + NO MSG + Chinese Food is a little bit like the idea of a unicorn swimming in a pot of gold at the end of a rainbow. Well Henry's is that unicorn!

80+% of the menu can be made Gluten Free (they don't bread the protein and use San-J tamari) and its very very good. We had the Hot and Sour Soup, Dry Sauteed Green Beans, Kung Pao Chicken, and Henry's Special (chicken, shrimp, and scallops). All amazing. Zero Complaints. Green beans still tasted fresh yet wok charred, the proteins were all cooked perfectly, and the veggies still crisp. Nice sticky white rice to support the dishes. Warning, if you order the soup, be prepared for about 8 bowls worth of soup to come out!

This is not run of the mill Chinese food. Its legitimate and high quality and will be our reliable go-to Chinese everytime we visit San Francisco.
author: Aaron D.

description:
I like the Financial District location but the food was greasier and even the farmer's salad was watery and bland.

Service was horrible. I don't expect fine dining but I expect someone to be present and to be a little helpful. The woman in her 40s seemed absent after we first saw her. All the walking I had to do from the back to the front register to say we were ready to order, would like some water, to make a second request for water, then to ask for our check would have fried a fitbit.
author: Robert T.

description:
After wandering around North Beach a bit and being disappointed that several of our favourite restaurants were closed at the time, I noticed Henry's Hunan right nearby and suggested we check it out, as I'd never been there before and my partner hadn't tried this particular location. We were both excited to have Chinese food and we were seated and our order taken promptly. 

My partner ordered the chicken and string beans, a standard dish that's one of his favourites, and a good way of comparing some of our other preferred Chinese restaurants to here. I picked out the hot and sour vegetables and we also ordered a plate of white rice, plus a glass of wine and a beer. We didn't have to wait too long before our meal came out (although separately, with about 2 minutes between each plate but whatever). 

I was a bit surprised that the hot and sour vegetables came in a pale sauce, I was expecting something reddish or orange at least but no matter, I piled rice on my plate and a few spoonfuls of veggies and dove in. The heat of this dish was intense, far spicier than I'm used to, but the sweetness of the bamboo shoots and the glass of wine plus the plainness of the rice helped dull it a bit. It was delicious and I ate about half easily. The rest I took home for later since it was that good, I didn't want to let it go to waste.

My partner noticed the chicken and string beans came with a chili black bean sauce, one of his favourite sauces. He thought his dish was amazing and ate every last bit of it.

Service was a tad slow but there seemed to be a large family gathering in the central table, we're talking 20+ people, so I can forgive them for it. Because of the layout of the restaurant, the noise of the large party was practically deafening, so be warned that this place can get pretty loud if there's a lot of people in it. Overall though, we'd happily return here, there were quite a few things on the menu that looked delicious and I would love to try more.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Staff was very attentive and friendly, restaurant was clean and nice ambiance, and the food was awesome!   My husband and I arrived around 6:30pm on a Saturday night and though there were a lot of people there, we had no trouble getting a good table. We ordered the:

pork fried rice (awesome, highly recommend)
chicken chow mein ( delicious, a little spicy) 
Dumplings (pork and veggie I believe, very tasty)
Kung pao chicken (spicy and delicious)
String beans and beef (don't recommend, too salty)
Tsing Tao beer (tasty) 

All in all, great experience, we would definitely go back! Wish this place was in San Jose.
author: Cristina G.

description:
Friendly staff, and some of the best hunan food in the city in my opinion. Reasonable prices, generous portions. and their hot and sour soup is to die for! 

On a personal note, I'm pescatarian and love spicy food, so this place hit the nail on the head.
author: Carissa W.

description: Best Chinese food in the city.  There is a reason Jerry Brown eats here when he is in town.  Luis and his staff are outstanding.
author: Jeff C.

description: When I think of San Francisco, I think of great Chinese food. It was a long day of driving and walking for miles, I just wanted some good, comforting Chinese food to welcome me to the city. I came across Henry's on Yelp! and its great reviews and decided to give it a try. We arrived around 7pm and it wasn't busy. Like a lot of Chinese restaurants, the entrees are served family style, so we ordered Kung Pao  Shrimp, Mongolian Beef, beef lo mein, pork fried rice, and for appetizer we ordered dumplings. Dumplings came out first and they were ok- not much flavor. I put the table side chili oil on them and their was no spice to the oil whatsoever. My asian friend said it's because the oil was mixed with bean curd? Entrees come out and everything is salty. I don't know how many waters and pots of tea we went through because of the saltiness of the dishes. The staff were all friendly and the prices were reasonable, but I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to friends and family.
author: Khrysten T.

description: Awesome Chinese food! Got the combination Chow Mein, harvest pork, Mongolian beef, onion cakes, and egg rolls. The harvest pork was my favorite. Come here!
author: Jeff L.

description:
It's authentic. Period.

I rarely leave comments on Chinese restaurants on Yelp because usually they are about Americanized Chinese food, but after having a fantastic dinner with my friends here I feel like I must do. 

My friends and I are from Hunan, and all I can say that this is soooooo authentic! We finished everything, including the juice from the dishes! They are so good to be left out.

Of course, you need to ask for the authentic menu which isn't meant for Americans. All the dishes on the authentic Chinese menu are good, so if you don't know Chinese, just pick a random one and you won't be disappointed! 

Remember, for the authentic Hunan food, never try those Americanized dishes like Broccoli beef, Chicken Chow mein or Hunan Beef. They are rubbish compared to the authentic ones. Use the real menu :-)
author: Hao Z.

description:
This is probably one of the best chinese restaurants in SF I tried in last 3 years.

It's very clean and food is very good. Service pretty friendly too.

There's also free tea for you.

At some point this is used to be my favourite place to get food around SF area. 

Sole reason I rated it less than 5 stars is because I know a place where you can get better food. But if you not willing to drive out to Daly City consider this as a 5 star review.
author: Artem M.

description:
Delicious! Nice 15 minute walk from Fisherman's Wharf. 
Garlic chicken, fried rice, and dumplings are yummy. Enjoy!
author: Crystal C.

description: My second Henry! Grant Ave. location in terms of quality spice it up Chinese food is just as great as the [larger space] Sansome St. location. Over the years, I've decided the one quintessential dish is the MARTY'S SPECIAL: Chicken, Smoked Pork & Ham, Bamboo Shoots, Onions, Carrots, and hot sauce. We get it every time, just as we get peppery, slurpy CHOW MEIN every time (with Shrimp!). Nonetheless, I acted upon a Yelp tip this last time and ordered HOT & SOUR BEEF, on a bed of white rice. Good lead, but I do think I'm doing it next time as HOT & SOUR PORK. Just a hunch the pork works better. Discoveries, discoveries... #classiceats
author: Sean C.

description:
I came in here for dinner on the eve of Chinese new year, one of my friends wanted to go to an authentic place for the holiday. The place didn't disappoint, it had all the makings of an authentic place - the didn't serve water until we asked for it, just tea to start, and they had a special menu (written in chinese) that you had to ask for.

There weren't many vegetarian options on the special chinese menu, but their normal one had plenty to choose from. I chose to get the home style bean curd. Now, it took way longer for my dish to come out compared to my friends (one ordered shrimp, and the other pork) which was slightly frustrating. But man, the tofu was really good! Super light texture, and a really light garlic, spicy sauce. It wasn't super filling, so if I came in hear really hungry I'd probably go with an appetizer and an entree. But with taste like this, I'm definitely coming back.
author: Amaresh S.

description: This place was amazing. Id recommend the prawn fried rice, it was like no fried rice I've ever had in my life.
author: kaitlin p.

description:
The menu on the website should be updated to indicate if the item is spicy.

We were driving and ordered off the website. I realize it is Hunan food and is often spicy. But we ordered simple items, such as chow mien and beef with string beans in black bean sauce, never imagining that they would spicy. They were not ridiculously hot, but hotter than my wife or I care for and hotter than my daughter would eat. We wound up throwing most of it away. I looked at the paper menu that I grabbed when I picked up and it did indicate that even the chow mien was spicy. I wish the website indicated that these items were spicy because I would have told them to make it mild.
author: Rob H.

description:
Stumbled into this restaurant after realizing there was going to be a two hour wait at the place we were originally planning to go to. Overall, we were pleasantly surprised and look forward to eating here again next time we are in North Beach.

Ambiance is very nice and everything is extremely clean. We ordered the Harvest Pork, Hot and Sour Chicken, and the Crescent Dumplings. The two entrees were good sized portions and perfectly spicy (definitely on the hot side). The pork dumplings were also quite good and surprisingly light.

4 stars only because service was a little slow but not terribly so. Took awhile to get water and hot tea as there was only one waitress.
author: Max J.

description: Our first time. Staff is friendly & service good. Food was great. We especially liked the Bean Curd with meat. Surprisingly, one of my nephew liked their pork spareribs sautéed with bell peppers and onions. And my other nephew liked the sweet & sour pork. Too bad they didn't have crispy fried noodle though.
author: Ariene S.

description:
Real good Chinese food prepared effortlessly for a gluten-free diet.  The selection can all be basically prepared GF except for the obvious stuff (wheat noodles and breaded deep fried items). My daughter has celiac and Henry's was a revelation to her. She said it perfectly - "this is so strange, having a full selection of Chinese food in an authentic Chinese restaurant. I'm so happy!!!"  I'm also a dyed-in-the-wool New York Chinese food biased snob (but fun at parties) and this place clears that hurdle with room to spare.  Oh the fried rice is a must.  Loved the garlic chicken and the hot and sour soup which was HOT and SOUR in all the right ways.  

Service was also really nice, fast and understanding.  

Thank you Henry's!  You made my daughter happy and so, of course, her father is happy and not just because I enjoyed the food as well.
author: Marc I.

description: Just moved to the area and went to the location on Grant.  I really enjoyed the food and the service.  Will definitely go back.
author: Cyrus U.

description:
Stumbled in on Friday night for a quick bite. Most of the restaurants nearby had a 30 minute to an hour wait, but Henry's was able to seat us right away. This location appears to be mostly take out, so if you want to eat in, it shouldn't be a problem!

The meat pie appetizer is great, it is kind of like a Chinese version of a Mexican Pizza from Taco Bell. The onion cake is definitely a go to. You really can't go wrong with any of the entrees. The waitress that helped us was fantastic. She was very attentive and extremely nice. She helped ensure that we made all the right choices in dishes. Each selection we made was perfect - pork, chicken, and vegetarian chow mein were great.

They will make the food as spicy as you would like. Also a nice surprise was that they had a number of decently priced bottles of wine.

Will definitely be back.
author: Ben B.

description:
This Hunan chain (there are 7 in all) restaurant opened in the North Beach area approximately a year ago.  The restaurant has a nice decor and I liked the floors.

We stopped in for lunch take out and the person taking our order at the register was so nice, he gave us a pot of tea to drink while we waited for our food. 
We got 5 orders for about $40: (all ordered w/o hot sauce)

1. Stir fried green beans - my favorite of all the dishes.  Good flavor and crispy.
2. Beef and broccoli - The vegt. was not overcooked and tasted OK.
3. Pork dumplings - wouldn't order again.  The wrap was sort of doughy, chewy.  It's really pot stickers not like the dumplings with a thin wrap and juicy center that you'd buy at San Tung on Irving Street. 
5. Chicken fried rice - was pretty good and good portions.  We ordered this by mistake because BFF's mom wanted chow fun and I thought she said chow fon (rice).  
6. Beef chow mein.  I didn't really like this dish that much.  You can get better chow mein from deli stores in Chinatown. 

With Chinatown being so close, I'd rather take the extra walk and head there for takeout food, but we were in a hurry so, we headed down from Telegraph Hill to this place.  
Not sure I'd make an effort to go here and fight the parking in North Beach for the food here. The place was empty for lunch on a Saturday.  Saw a couple of other customers come for take out 'tho.  They sell their Hunan chili sauce in plastic jars at the counter.  Invented by the original Henry's of Hunan.
author: Ry T.

description: Excellent food! We had the Mongolian beef, shredded pork, dumplings and hot and sour soup. Everything was delicious, but the spicy dumplings were my favorite! The service was great. Lewis was very sweet and made sure that we were taken care of. Thanks, Lewis! We will definitely be returning and recommending. :)
author: Sam B.

description:
I've been going to Henry's with my family since I was 5 years old, I'm now 26, and it's still my go-to Chinese restaurant in the world! The new North Beach location is just as good if not better than the other Henry's locations.

My ideal order is:

--Steamed dumplings  
--Diana's meat pie
--Bean curd with meat sauce ( a MUST!)
--Chicken curry
--String beans with meat sauce
--Side of white rice
(All of this is equally delicious if you order spicy or mild!! I prefer very spicy)
author: Alex C.

description:
Everytime I think I'm going to make it through some decent Chinese, I end up completely disappointed. I did some research this time, no shooting from the hip rash decision making without thought. I looked upon Yelp to show me some good Chinese. After looking through many reviews, I came upon Henry's Hunan. It's a hole in the wall Chinese place in between the financial district and Chinatown, a stone's throw away. 

The place looked kind of dirty as I've expected Chinese restaurants to be. Chinese places aren't known for aesthetics, if you want ambience, you go to PF Chang's. I look around, just a bunch of low-end office worker types. This was a mission to find some decent, good, cheap Chinese. And I thought this was the place. 

I sat down and saw about 10 cooks in the kitchen all yelling and getting loud. So far so good. Then I ordered from the menu. I carefully decided upon a beef and green bean lunch. After about 3 minutes, my lunch came to my table. It wasn't beef. It was chicken. I guess I must look stupid to these guys. Or maybe they're just stupid? Ok, didn't want to push the issue because I know how these folks can get. So I decide to take a leap of faith and try their chicken and green bean lunch. 

Folks, I can't stress upon this any further. DO NOT COME HERE. The food was so terrible. It was just downright inedible. So awful. It was a misadventure into the worst tasting Chinese food ever. With 10 cooks in the kitchen, not one of these mothers know how to cook a meal. I can't say anything good about the place. It's just horrible. The owner of the restaurant was yelling at this young Chinese girl who really looked lost. She could likely be someone in indentured servitude that you always hear about but never act upon because you think, no, not here, not in America. 

IF YOU VALUE YOUR LIFE, DO NOT EAT HERE. The food is tasteless, mushy, nasty and just downright crap. Even the rice was crappy. I mean seriously? Chinese people not able to do rice right? How do you screw up rice? That's like French not able to bake a good loaf of bread. Really sad. This has to be the WORST CHINESE restaurant in the City.  All of these 5 star reviews given to this place on Yelp are fraudulent. 

I GIVE THIS JOINT ZERO STARS.
author: Tiffany R.

description: As Chinese, I think this is one of the  best hunan restaurant in the city, very traditional and yammy！ I like hunan pork with chili the most.
author: 炯

description:
Really tasty food and clean, casual vibe. Service was friendly and efficient. They love to make their dishes spicy so if that's your thing you're in business. I went medium spice and it was just enough. 

Tons of Gluten Free options listed right in the menu and Tamari sauce is available for the table as well. Such a treat to have gluten free Asian food as it's very rare that a place uses GF Soy sauce. Such a small adjustment with such great results. I wish more quality Chinese restaurants would follow suit.
author: Jeff G.

description:
I have no idea how people have been rating this place so high. We just tried orange chicken, eggplant, dumplings and onion cake.
Dumplings were the only thing that tasted good. 
The orange chicken is a big disappointment. The onion cake was baked flour, with no onions. The eggplant, is just not edible.
The food also take a long time to arrive even though the restaurant is quite empty.
This place does not meet any standard close to 1 star.
author: Gee B.

description: Incredible Chinese food, and pretty good portion size, at unbelievably low prices for SF!  Loved my shrimp and cabbage, though I would recommend ordering it mild.
author: Gerry C.

description:
I ordered the famous "Diane's Meat Pie".

When it arrived, I was trying to remember if I was still at a Chinese restaurant.

Its essentially a sandwich of ground beef, onion and lettuce in this delicious butter crisp dough.

Like nothing ever seen before in any Chinese restaurant. 

It was good though!

Try it!
author: Joel Z.

description: Awesome, clean restaurant. Some of the best Kung Pow Chicken I've had!  Friendly staff.  Perfect late night food after hitting up the pubs in the surrounding area.
author: Dallas D.

description:
Our first trip to Chinatown ended in a hike up to Henry's thanks to the reviews here on Yelp. I had a hard time believing a five-star restaurant could be reasonably priced. Boy am I glad we took the chance.

Our waitress recommended the meat pie to start, and it was excellent. It's served in four slices that are probably big enough to each be an appetizer alone.

I always order a house special when I'm at a new restaurant, and at Henry's those specialties are smoked Hunan-style. I decided to get the Marty's Special, because I thought it was funny, since my name's Marty and I don't see it often.

The waitress thought I had been here before and said I knew how to order, because the Marty's Special is fantastic. The chicken in it was good enough but the pork was worth the price alone. Tender and smoky, it was easily the best I've had yet.

We also got the fried rice and the hot and sour chicken, which were both good but didn't hold a candle next tithe meat pie and the smoked pork. Next time we'll just get those two and share; it's plenty for two people.
author: Marty A.

description:
Most of their dishes can be made gluten free!  Try their smoked ham dish and the Henry's special!  These are my go to favorites here hands down!

This is around the street from my girlfriend's place so it's where we go when we're feeling lazy or simply have a craving.  Having a gluten-challenged immune system it's one of the few Chinese places I can eat at and not worry about having a stomach ache or swollen hands afterwards and it's strategically located right down the street from Tope which has a great happy hour until 10 pm.

*emoji of pagoda here*
Enjoy!
author: Theron L.

description:
Less and less authentic, and still arrogant as heck. Disappointing.

The main condiment used seems to be salt, and a lot of it.
author: George T.

description:
Hard place to rate.  

The chicken chow mein is really good (spicy and celery with cabbage make it awesome).  The garlic chicken is meh (one note flavor, and it's not even garlicky-- just kinda...soy saucy?).  I think dishes are hit or miss.

However, the pricing here is amazingly fair for the neighborhood!  Their $1.50 rice is like double the size of what other restaurants usually give.  Very generous proportions.  I guess you get what you pay for (almost like Panda Express but bit fresher food).  

The restaurant itself is very clean and has wooden floors/benches, and the service was awesome!
author: Lily N.

description: We had a fantastic lunch here. The restaurant is clean and the service very attentive. We ate Hunan spare ribs which came chopped into ti lets and had a black bean sauce with onion and peppers. Best ribs !! So good. The combo chow mein rounded out the meal. We will be back'
author: Brian D.

description: We opted for the Sweet n Sour Chicken with an extra egg roll a d Pork Fried Rice. My wife and I shared a meal (huge portions) The service was outstanding and the food a 4 star. Close to attractions and shops.
author: Robert N.

description: Simply the best in my opinion. A must visit when in San Fran! Honey walnut shrimp is fantastic
author: Chris W.

description:
I have been here for more than 3 times...

The servies is amazin... 

Waiter is more than helpful. He always recommend good stuff. And every time I am amazed by the taste of the food.

It is located in a busy area. So plan ahead for parking.
author: Steve L.

description:
This is a decent place if you wanted to eat slightly spicy, somewhat Americanized Chinese food. 

The portions were pretty good for the price. The service was very friendly in general. I asked for all the dishes I ordered to be extra spicy, they complied and it was pretty good.

My only complaint is that some dishes were too salty for me.
author: XiaoChuan Y.

description: Absolutely the best hot and sour soup I've ever had. Run, don't walk, to this terrific place.
author: Bob H.

description:
HUNAN HOT.

The restaurant is a perfect place to for quick, fast, chinese food to-go. The restaurant tries to go for a healthy themed Chinese restaurant.

FOOD: Chicken with mixed vegetables: Great dish that comes with sauteed chicken, bell peppers, onions, mushroom, carrots, and scallion. The sauce is not too heavy and it definitely tastes healthy without having you fill like you have over eaten.

Onion Cakes: These are also great for an appetizer. The Onion Cakes are fried, fluffy and crispy, but can use a little bit more flavor and more green onions.

SERVICE: The service here is great. The owners of the restaurant try to make sure you have everything you need. They also offered tea while you waited if the wait was too long. 

AMBIANCE: The restaurant looks modern with red wood floors and chairs. It's a typical modern restaurant that you would expect but serves chinese food.

Overall: Great place for take out in North Beach if you are looking for something quick to eat!
author: Stephen C.

description:
I love this place. I live half a block down and am so glad it's right here. The food is consistently fabulous - if you like hot Kung Pao, it's amazing here. Ask for it extra spicy, and they really give it to you! A BIG deal here is the fact that I've never had a bad piece of chicken come out of here. You know the kind, the chewy, ambigiously grey, fatty stuff with cartilage still attached? The reason you always hesitate to order chicken at a Chinese restaurant? Yeah, none of that here.

The chow mein is cooked very well and the vegetable fried rice (which I tend to judge a lot of places on), is just how I like it! Just enough egg and the vegetables are right. And the staff is the friendliest I've ever met.
author: A S.

description: I have no clue how this place got such high rating. It really isn't that good for Asian food. But my friend and I might have made a really wrong choice. The green onion pancake has no flavor won tong soup tastes cheap and effortless. Got veggie dish it's a bit over cooked the gongbao chicken is okay but not the best. Do not really recommend. Won't come back again.
author: Yulin K.

description: Came here  for lunch today and generally enjoyed the meal. I can understand if some people think the food is too salty, or a bit too spicy, because both can certainly be true for some dishes. The rock cod, spare ribs, and shrimp that I shared with my co-workers were all saucy and stir fried. I am a fan of Americanized Chinese food, so if you like Panda Express, I'm 100% sure you'll find more than a handful of dishes you would really enjoy here. Dishes here are meant to be shared family style and range from $7-$12 each. When I came here at 1pm, the place was not busy at all. If you're looking for some fast Chinese food and are in North Beach area, I would recommend Henry's.
author: Austin W.

description: I only gave it 4 stars simply because I've only been here once.  It was very good.  Meat pies were great.  All the food tasted very fresh and health.  My wife's friend did complain that her food was a little too spicy.  It was pretty tough understanding the waiter through the accent.  I would totally recommend this place.  Good luck with parking.
author: Daryl B.

description: Food was decent and portions were good, but hard to complain given the low prices.
